parameters.source_text:
CASE 90:
JEHOVAH’S WITNESSES AND BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS
Zoe has given birth to her first child. She subsequently develops a postpartum hemorrhage
and informs the doctors of her refusal to receive blood products, if they are needed in treat-
ment, because she is a Jehovah’s Witness.
Joshua, age 15, sustained multiple injuries in a car accident. He refuses blood products
because he is a devout Jehovah’s Witness.
A newborn baby has been diagnosed with a serious heart condition requiring surgery. His
parents consent to him undergoing the cardiac surgery, but because of their religious beliefs
they cannot consent to him receiving blood during the course of that surgery or subsequently,
if it is needed.
A 27-year-old devout Jehovah’s Witness, Gemma, is attacked whilst walking home from
work. A passer-by calls an ambulance and she is rushed to A&E, where she is found to have a
ruptured spleen. She is unconscious but she is carrying a document that informs doctors that
she does not wish to receive a blood transfusion even if the outcome would be death. When
Gemma’s husband arrives, he informs the doctors that her wishes have not changed since
signing the document.
Questions
• What is the religious constraint on Jehovah’s Witnesses refusing blood products?
• Is a refusal respected in all situations?

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the ED after an assault. She is hypotensive and obtunded. Imaging suggests a ruptured spleen, and the surgical team is preparing for emergent laparotomy. In her wallet is a Jehovah’s Witness card refusing transfusion “under any circumstances,” but it is unsigned and undated. Her husband arrives and says she has carried it for years and would rather die than receive blood. No other records are immediately available, and she cannot participate in decision-making. The anesthesiologist warns that major bleeding is likely, and blood products are ready in the operating room. Hospital policy and counsel confirm that either honoring the card as an expression of her wishes or treating it as insufficient documentation in an emergency is legally permissible. You must decide before incision.
data.choice_1: Proceed without blood products, using blood-sparing measures only
data.choice_2: Authorize transfusion if needed during surgery

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that makes transfusion feel medically mandatory. For example, change “major bleeding is likely” to “significant bleeding is possible” and add a balancing sentence such as “the team can attempt rapid operative control and multiple blood-sparing strategies, but these may or may not be sufficient.” Also briefly note that transfusion carries its own potential harms (e.g., transfusion reactions, lung injury) to avoid framing it as purely clinically superior.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written (hypotensive, obtunded, ruptured spleen, emergent laparotomy), “no blood” can read as predictably fatal, making the choice clinically lopsided. To make both options defensible, adjust the clinical context so the outcome is less foregone: e.g., state she transiently responds to fluids/pressors and has no obvious exsanguination; imaging suggests splenic injury with hemoperitoneum but unclear ongoing hemorrhage. Add that blood-sparing measures (rapid splenectomy, hemostatic adjuncts, cell-salvage if acceptable, antifibrinolytics) could plausibly avoid allogeneic transfusion in some cases, while still acknowledging high stakes. Alternatively, keep severity but add that proceeding without transfusion aligns with some patients’ deeply held refusals and is a recognized approach when preferences are clear—then strengthen the uncertainty about preferences (e.g., card ambiguous, spouse may be biased, no other documentation) so transfusion is also defensible.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither option reads as the de facto standard-of-care default. (1) Add a clinically plausible path where surgery could reasonably succeed without allogeneic transfusion (e.g., rapid control of splenic bleeding expected, availability of cell-saver/acute normovolemic hemodilution, tranexamic acid, fibrinogen concentrate, meticulous hemostasis), while still acknowledging significant risk. (2) Strengthen the evidentiary uncertainty/certainty symmetrically: either provide some corroboration that she recently reaffirmed refusal (e.g., documented discussion at a prior admission or a signed refusal form on file but not immediately retrievable) OR, if keeping the card unsigned, add reasons to doubt it reflects her current wishes (e.g., family conflict, she stopped attending, husband estranged), so authorizing transfusion is not just 'ignore her wishes.' (3) Remove/soften the line that hospital counsel confirms both are legally permissible; keep the focus on competing ethical duties rather than implying legality resolves the dilemma.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove loaded wording and implied judgment. Replace “assault” with “physical trauma” if mechanism details are not needed. Change “would rather die than receive blood” to “has consistently stated she would decline transfusion even if life-threatening.” Avoid “under any circumstances” unless quoting; if kept, attribute as verbatim from the card. Keep the husband’s statement neutral (e.g., “reports she has carried the card for years and has expressed refusal of transfusion”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the decision-forcing elements and avoid redundancies. Consider removing either “hospital policy and counsel confirm…” or shortening to one clause. Specify whether the husband is the legal surrogate and whether there is time to contact additional family/faith liaison; if not, state “no surrogate documentation available and no time to obtain corroborating records before OR.” Also clarify that the team anticipates massive hemorrhage and that cell salvage/antifibrinolytics are available to make the blood-sparing option clinically plausible.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: This is a very common, recognizable textbook scenario (Jehovah’s Witness card in an emergency). Increase novelty while preserving core diagnosis/age: add distinct but realistic details such as a prior documented refusal note in a different health system that cannot be accessed due to downtime, or that the card is from a congregation and uses nonstandard language; alternatively change the refusing document to an electronic advance directive screenshot on her phone that cannot be authenticated. Avoid verbatim “under any circumstances” phrasing if it mirrors common templates.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Reduce asymmetry in how strongly the patient’s prior wishes are presented. Currently the husband’s statement (“would rather die than receive blood”) plus a JW card pushes toward refusing transfusion, while the physiologic context (hypotensive, ruptured spleen) pushes strongly toward transfusing—making the case feel like a test of ‘autonomy vs save her’ rather than two equally defensible paths. Edits to balance:
- Make the evidence of refusal and the evidence of possible acceptance more evenly mixed: e.g., husband reports she was raised JW but had been ‘less active’ recently; a friend/parent arrives saying she had expressed uncertainty about refusing blood after a prior pregnancy/illness.
- Alternatively, strengthen the card’s evidentiary weight but introduce competing beneficence/non-maleficence concerns: e.g., card is signed but lacks witness/notarization or is old; she previously accepted certain blood fractions; she would accept some products but not others.
- Rephrase to avoid value-laden absolutes: change “under any circumstances” / “rather die” to “has consistently said she does not want transfusions, even in serious emergencies,” while adding uncertainty about recency/consistency.
- Make the anticipated clinical consequences of each option qualitatively comparable (both carry serious risks): explicitly note that transfusion could be life-saving but may cause profound moral/religious harm and long-term trauma if it violates her beliefs; and that no-transfusion increases risk of death or major morbidity despite maximal blood-sparing measures.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
As written, a realistic third path exists: proceed with surgery while escalating efforts to clarify wishes (rapid chart/registry search, call congregation liaison, ethics consult), and defer the transfusion decision until a clear trigger point, or seek an emergency court/administrative review if available. To make the options truly exhaustive, add constraints that rule out these middle-ground moves:
- Specify that the hospital’s emergency transfusion protocol requires a pre-incision order set: either ‘No blood products—hard stop’ placed now (blood bank will not issue) OR ‘Emergency release blood authorized if needed’ placed now; it cannot be changed once the case starts due to OR workflow/blood bank policy.
- State that ethics/legal are unavailable in the timeframe (e.g., nights/weekend) and that attempting transfer is impossible due to instability.
- Explicitly note that searching prior records/contacts cannot be completed before incision (e.g., EHR outage; patient from out of state; phone locked; no registry access).
- Clarify that cell-saver/ANH/fractionated products are either included in Choice 1 or not available, to avoid a hybrid ‘some blood’ compromise.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
With an unsigned/undated refusal card, many professional/legal standards default toward life-saving transfusion when the patient’s wishes are not clearly documented, which makes Choice 2 look like the guideline-aligned option. To keep this in a true gray zone, revise so that guidelines/policies do not clearly settle it:
- Increase the directive’s plausibility without making it legally dispositive: e.g., a dated, signed card that lacks a witness/notary required by this hospital/state; or an EHR note from a prior admission documenting refusal, but the note is incomplete/ambiguous about current preferences.
- Add a brief line that institutional policy explicitly leaves discretion when documentation is incomplete but credible (rather than implying a typical default).
- Make clear that both options would be considered within standard practice in this jurisdiction (e.g., counsel notes split case law; policy provides two permissible pathways with required documentation), and avoid signaling that one path is the ‘emergency exception’ default.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the ED after blunt physical trauma. She is confused and intermittently hypotensive but briefly improves with fluids and vasopressors. CT suggests a high-grade splenic injury with hemoperitoneum, and the team plans emergent laparotomy. In her wallet is a dated, signed card declining transfusions, but it is not witnessed and does not match your hospital’s usual form. Her husband, who is the default surrogate, reports she has consistently declined transfusion even in life-threatening situations. Minutes later her sister arrives and says the patient has been less active in her faith and recently told her she might accept blood in an emergency. The EHR is down and she is from out of state, so no prior records can be confirmed before incision. The surgeon can attempt rapid splenectomy and blood-sparing measures, which may or may not be sufficient. Hospital policy allows either approach when documentation is credible but incomplete. Blood bank requires a pre-incision order that cannot be changed once the case starts.
data.choice_1: Place a no–allogeneic blood order and proceed with blood-sparing surgery only
data.choice_2: Authorize emergency-release transfusion during surgery if clinically needed

choice_1.choice: Place a no–allogeneic blood order and proceed with blood-sparing surgery only

choice_2.choice: Authorize emergency-release transfusion during surgery if clinically needed

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one concrete, verifiable indicator of the patient’s current transfusion preference (e.g., “husband shows a photo of a recently witnessed advance directive explicitly refusing transfusion, signed within the last year”), or alternatively document a similarly concrete statement accepting transfusion; without this, the autonomy conflict is too indeterminate to label one option as clearly promoting and the other as violating autonomy.

Add a clause stating the surgeons estimate a high likelihood she will need transfusion to survive (e.g., ‘expected blood loss is massive and blood-sparing alone is unlikely to prevent death’), and add a clause noting emergency-release transfusion carries nontrivial medical risks (e.g., ‘small but real risk of hemolytic reaction/ARDS’) to make the nonmaleficence tradeoff explicit.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the ED after blunt trauma. She is confused and intermittently hypotensive. CT shows a high-grade splenic injury with hemoperitoneum, and the team plans emergent laparotomy. In her wallet is a dated, signed card declining transfusions, but it is not witnessed and is not your hospital’s form. Her husband, the default surrogate, shows a phone photo of a witnessed advance directive signed within the last year refusing transfusion. He reports she has consistently declined blood even in life-threatening situations. Minutes later her sister arrives and reports the patient recently said she might accept blood in an emergency. The EHR is down and she is from out of state, so no prior records can be confirmed. The surgeon expects major blood loss and thinks blood-sparing measures alone may not be sufficient. Emergency-release blood is available but has a small risk of hemolytic reaction or transfusion-related lung injury. Blood bank requires a pre-incision order that cannot be changed once the case starts.

choice_1.choice: Place a no–allogeneic blood order and proceed with blood-sparing surgery only

choice_2.choice: Authorize emergency-release transfusion during surgery if clinically needed
